Catalytic behaviour of various metal-alumina catalysts Silvia V. Gredig, Ren~ A. Koeppel, Alfons Baiker* Department of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology. ETH-Zentrum, CH-8092 Ziirich, Switzerland Received 27 January 1997; received in revised form 6 March 1997: accepted 6 March 1997 Abstract The synthesis of methylamines from CO2, H2 and NH3 has been investigated over various metal-alumina catalysts (Cu, Ag, Ni, Pt, Co and Fe) prepared by coprecipitation. Catalytic tests were carried out using a fixed-bed reactor in the temperature range 473-573 K and at 0.6 MPa total pressure. Among all metal catalysts highest methylamine production rates were obtained with the copper-alumina catalysts, affording a distribution of monomethylamine (MMA):dimethylamine (DMA) : trimethylamine (TMA) of 72 : 15 : 13 at 513 K. Increasing the ammonia concentration in the feed resulted in improved selectivity to MMA. By-products observed over copper-alumina were carbon monoxide, originating from the reverse water gas shift reaction, and water. Ni, Co, Fe and Pt showed little methylamine production, but significant methane formation, whereas Ag produced only CO, H20 and HCN. (~; 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords: Methylamine synthesis; Carbon dioxide; Metal-alumina: Copper; Nickel: Iron; Cobalt; Platinum; Silver 1. Introduction The large scale availability of CO2, produced in any combustion process, renders it a suitable starting material for the synthesis of valuable chemicals and fuels. Although most of the work in carbon oxides hydrogenation has concentrated on CO [ 1 ], the synth- esis of methanol from carbon dioxide and hydrogen is well known [ 1-3]. On the contrary, the formation of organo-nitrogen compounds such as amines has only been described starting from CO, H2 and NH3 [4-6]. Several processes have been patented, that convert *Corresponding author. Tel.: +41 1 6323153; fax: +41 1 6321163: e-mail: baiker@tech,chem.ethz,ch CO/H2/NH3 mixtures to alkylamines in the presence of modified Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [7-9] or cop- per-based catalysts [10,11]. Other products formed include methane and lower hydrocarbons [5,10,11 ], acetonitrile and HCN [6], as well as N,N-dimethyl- formamide [7]. Recently, we have shown that methyl- amines can be produced from CO2, H2 and NH3 over copper-alumina catalysts [ 13,14]. In industrial processes methylamines are produced by the exothermic reaction of methanol with ammonia over solid acidic dehydrogenation catalysts such as silica-alumina. The thermodynamically favoured pro- duct of this reaction is trimethylamine (TMA) [12], whereas monomethylamine (MMA) and dimethyl- amine (DMA) are of major commercial interest. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 (i~ 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Gredig et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 249-260 Methylamines are valuable chemicals for the synthesis of a broad range of products. They are used in pesticide production, solvent production, and water treatment. Intrigued by our previous studies with copper- alumina catalysts [13,14], where MMA was the main amine product, we tested other metal-alumina catalysts, including Ag, Ni, Pt, Co and Fe. Here we report the catalytic behaviour of these metal- alumina catalysts in the reaction of carbon dioxide, hydrogen and ammonia to methylamines (MMA, DMA, TMA). solution of potassium hydroxide at 353 K and aged for 96 h at room temperature. The pure alumina showed no catalytic activity, neither for amine synthesis nor for any other reaction under the experimental conditions used. Consequently we can state that the catalytic behaviour of all tested catalysts was mainly determined by the metal com- ponent. As concerns the activity for amine production (MMA, DMA, TMA), highest rates were observed with copper catalysts. The methylamine distribution changed significantly depending on the metal catalyst. For the copper catalysts no marked dependence of the amine distribution on copper loading was observed. Several catalysts (Ni-2, Pt-2, Co-4 and Fe-35) showed a high selectivity to MMA, but with low production rates. CO, H20 and HCN (only with Cu-9) were the by-products detected with copper catalysts, whereas all the other metals showed significant methane for- mation, and in the case of Fe (acetonitrile and ethyl- amines) and Co (acetonitrile) even C-C bond formation. 3.3. The reac- tion temperature and the NH3/CO2 ratio strongly influenced both NH3 conversion and methylamine distribution. The temperature dependence of the pro- duct distribution, presented in Fig. 1 for Cu-27, shows that all three methylamines were produced over the whole temperature range (473-573 K) investigated, with MMA being favoured at higher temperatures. Discussion All catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation in a potassium containing solution and were thoroughly washed with distilled water after filtration. On the surface of some catalysts (A1203, Pt-2, Fe-35 and Fe- 4), traces of potassium (< 1 at%) were detected by XPS analysis. Consequently a promoting effect of potas- sium cannot be ruled out completely with these cata- lysts. The pure alumina component, prepared in the same way as the metal-alumina catalysts, was not active for the methylamine synthesis starting from CO2/Hz/NH3. Thus the catalytic behaviour of the tested metal- alumina catalysts is governed by the metal-compo- nent. Under standard conditions the various metal-alu- mina catalysts did not show significant deactivation during catalytic tests. Deactivation of copper, nickel and cobalt catalysts in the presence of ammonia and methylamines can be caused by the formation of inactive metal nitrides (Cu, Ni, Co) as well as by the formation of carbonaceous deposits and metal carbides (Ni, Co) in the absence of hydrogen [21- 23]. However, the relatively large hydrogen partial pressure of the reactant gas (60 mol%) in methylamine synthesis renders these deactivation processes unlike- ly. The mono-alkylated amine MMA, which is also of commercial interest, was the prevailing methylamine produced with all catalysts. Interestingly, the dispro- portionation of the MMA product (Eqs. (1)-(3)), which is also catalysed by metal-alumina catalysts [22-24], seems to have little influence on the amine distribution. 2MMA~+~-DMA + NH3 MMA + DMA,,~-TMA + NH3 2DMA~-TMA + MMA (1) (2) (3) TMA would be the thermodynamically favoured methylamine, if the disproportionation would control the amine distribution [24]. However, the dispropor- tionation reactions seem not to control the distribution of the methylamines. Likewise as observed for the deactivation processes, higher hydrogen partial pres- sures were found to inhibit the disproportionation of methylamines [23]. Another unfavourable side reaction, which can occur with nickel, cobalt and iron catalysts, is hydro- cracking of the product amines (Eqs. (4)-(6)) [23]. The comparably low amine production observed with nickel, cobalt and iron catalyst could be explained by the occurrence of hydrocracking reactions. Conse- quently, a minor contribution of hydrocracking reac- tions to methane formation cannot be ruled out at higher temperatures, although CH4 is expected to be predominantly formed by direct hydrogenation of CO2. MMA + H2~.~--CH4 + NH3 DMA + 2H2~-2CH4 + NH3 TMA + 3H2~-3CH4 + NH3 (4) (5) (6) As regards the major products identified with the different metal-alumina catalysts, the results can be explained in terms of the contribution of four compet- ing reactions, leading to methanol/methylamines (reaction I), carbon monoxide (reaction II), hydrogen cyanide (reaction III), and methane/Fischer-Tropsch products (reaction IV), as illustrated in Fig. 7. Metha- nol synthesis occurs only in the absence of ammonia and is observed for the catalysts containing copper, nickel, or platinum. The fact that methanol disappears in the product mixture in the presence of ammonia with these catalysts indicates, that an intermediate in methanol synthesis reacts with ammonia to the amine (MMA) [13,14]. The involvement of an aldehyde-type intermediate has also been suggested by Vedage et al. [4,28] on the basis of chemical trapping experi- ments with amines in the synthesis of methanol from CO and H2. Kliger et al. [5] also proposed a pathway, where n-alkylamines are synthesised from CO/H2/ NH3 over fused iron catalysts by the reaction of ammonia and hydrogen with a surface intermediate, from which n-alkanols are obtained in the absence of NH3. To form the di- and tri-alkylated methylamines (DMA and TMA), MMA or DMA are proposed to react with the formaldehyde intermediate, instead of ammonia. Carbon monoxide, produced by the reverse water gas shift reaction, is formed on all catalysts. At 573 K the RWGS reaction is dominant for the highly loaded copper catalysts and for the catalysts Pt-2, Co-4, and Fe-4. Note that in the absence of ammonia substan- tially more CO is observed with all catalysts at 513 K, except Co-4, which showed increased CO production upon addition of ammonia to the CO2/H2 feed. As expected from the literature [16-19], methane is produced from CO2/H2 with the catalysts containing cobalt, nickel, and platinum. No hydrocarbons other than methane are found with these catalysts, which is in accordance with results from the literature [19,27], showing that in contrast to reactions starting from CO/ H2, CH4 is almost exclusively formed from CO2/H2. In CO/H2 reactions, methane and higher hydrocarbons are produced from adsorbed CO via a dissociative mechanism [16,27], whereas in CO2/I-I2 reactions methane was reported to be formed via an oxygenated S.V. Gredig et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 162 (1997) 249-260 259 species (formate) as pivotal surface intermediate [27]. Similarly as observed for methanol and CO, methane formation is suppressed by the addition of ammonia to the CO2/H2 feed at 513 K with the Co, Ni, or Pt containing catalysts. In addition to methane as the predominant product, catalyst Fe-35 produced traces of hydrocarbons and alkylamines with two or more C-atoms at tempera- tures above 553 K (reactions of type IV). A reaction scheme for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was sug- gested by Henrici-Oliv6 and Oliv6 [29,30], taking into account results obtained with CO/Hz/NH3 mixtures. Higher hydrocarbons are thereby formed by carbon monoxide insertion into an alkyl-metal bond. Kliger et al, [5] reported that the reaction of CO]Hz/NH3 mix- tures over Fe catalysts yields an unselective range of products with a Schulz-Flory distribution. In the present study of methylamine synthesis from CO2, H2 and NH3, products with one carbon atom (methane, methylamines) were prevailing due to the compara- tively low concentration of CO under reaction condi- tions. Besides the products described above, HCN (Cu-9, Ag-44, Fe-35, Fe-4) and acetonitrile (Co-4, Fe-35) were produced under certain conditions. Formation of HCN and of nitrile species was occasionally observed in the reaction of CO/H2/NH3-mixtures [6,28]. Nitrile species can also occur via a side reaction during dehydroamination of alcohols with ammonia at higher temperatures [23]. An often postulated pathway to HCN involves the formation of intermediate isocya- nate species on the surface [31-33]. 5. Conclusions Among the metal-alumina catalysts investigated (Cu, Ag, Pt, Ni, Co, Fe), the highly loaded copper catalysts Cu-47 and Cu-27 were most active for methylamine synthesis. For all catalysts producing methylamines, the addition of ammonia to the feed suppressed methanol formation. With more than 5 tool% ammonia in the feed methanol could not be detected any more at 513 K. All catalysts active for methylamine synthesis at 513 K, produced methyl- amines at a higher rate compared to methanol (without ammonia in the feed). This indicates that for all these catalysts ammonia and hydrogen are reacting with a surface intermediate, probably adsorbed formalde- hyde, which reacts to methanol in the absence of ammonia. Methane formation is favoured compared to amine synthesis at higher temperature with all methane producing catalysts (Ni, Pt, Co, Fe). Carbon monoxide was formed via RWGS reaction on all catalysts. Except for the nickel containing catalyst, for which carbon monoxide formation decreased on the cost of methane formation at higher temperatures, carbon monoxide formation increased with higher temperature. HCN formation was observed with Cu-9, Ag-44, Fe-35 and Fe-4. On the pure alumina no HCN was formed, indicating that the metal is crucial for HCN formation under the conditions given. Tel.: +41 1 6323153; fax: +41 1 6321163 The synthesis of methylamines from CO2, H2 and NH3 has been investigated over various metal-alumina catalysts (Cu, Ag, Ni, Pt, Co and Fe) prepared by coprecipitation. Catalytic tests were carried out using a fixed-bed reactor in the temperature range 473–573 K and at 0.6 MPa total pressure. Among all metal catalysts highest methylamine production rates were obtained with the copper-alumina catalysts, affording a distribution of monomethylamine (MMA): dimethylamine (DMA): trimethylamine (TMA) of 72 : 15 : 13 at 513 K. Increasing the ammonia concentration in the feed resulted in improved selectivity to MMA. By-products observed over copper-alumina were carbon monoxide, originating from the reverse water gas shift reaction, and water. Ni, Co, Fe and Pt showed little methylamine production, but significant methane formation, whereas Ag produced only CO, H2O and HCN.
